sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_1:
Using the method of cofactors, find the determinant of the following 3x3 matrix:

$$
\begin{vmatrix}
2 & -1 & 0\\
3 & 4 & 2 \\
1 & 2 & -2
\end{vmatrix}
$$
message_2:
To find the determinant of the given 3x3 matrix using the method of cofactors, we will expand along the first row:

$$
\det(A) = 2 \cdot C_{11} - (-1) \cdot C_{12} + 0 \cdot C_{13}
$$

where $C_{ij}$ is the cofactor of the element in the $i$-th row and $j$-th column. Now, we need to find the cofactors:

$$
C_{11} = \begin{vmatrix}
4 & 2 \\
2 & -2
\end{vmatrix} = (4 \cdot (-2)) - (2 \cdot 2) = -8 - 4 = -12
$$

$$
C_{12} = \begin{vmatrix}
3 & 2 \\
1 & -2
\end{vmatrix} = (3 \cdot (-2)) - (1 \cdot 2) = -6 - 2 = -8
$$

$$
C_{13} = \begin{vmatrix}
3 & 4 \\
1 & 2
\end{vmatrix} = (3 \cdot 2) - (1 \cdot 4) = 6 - 4 = 2
$$

Now, substitute the cofactors back into the determinant formula:

$$
\det(A) = 2 \cdot (-12) - (-1) \cdot (-8) + 0 \cdot 2 = -24 - 8 = -32
$$

So, the determinant of the given matrix is -32.
